title: Do you have to be good in math to get into digital forensics? - Quora

response.answer_text: Good question Jeffrey. At minimum you should be able to be sufficiently capable of high school level mathematics such as algebra, a smattering of trig and better-calculus. If you’ll be studying cryptography and security you’ll have to be somewhat proficient in advanced algebra and Python. You can get an idea from Bill Buchanan’s channel as to what cryptography involves. If you are a generally logical person but weak in math, you can master math easily with supplemental non-credit courses at the college you’re attending. From a personal perspective I have always been terrible at math but since taking classes and further independent studies, I’ve found it opened up a new world for me and my practice. Concluding, math is an important part of your studies but logic skills will get you a long way.

I did some research and you typically need at least at cs degree or engineer degree with the following soft skills. Network skills, including TCP/IP-based network communications (much of modern forensics involves reading network traces) Windows, UNIX and Linux operating systems C, C++, C#, Java and similar programming languages Computer hardware and software systems Operating system installation, patching and configuration Backup and archiving technologies Cryptography principles eDiscovery tools (NUIX, Relativity, Clearwell, etc.) Forensic software applications (e.g. EnCase, FTK, Helix, Cellebrite, XRY, etc.) Data processing skills in electronic disclosure environments Evidence handling procedures and ACPO guidelines Cloud computing If you're bad at math forget about the other requirements listed. Here's the rest of the site: How to Become a Forensics Expert | Requirements for Computer Forensics Jobs

No; you don’t need to be good at math to get into digital forensics. The majority of people working in the field do not have technical degrees and probably have not taken any math courses beyond what they took in high school or what was required to meet their general education requirement in college.
